I'm still rather new to JUnit (although I've purchased at least two 
(2) JU=
nit books)and I'm finally getting around to actually using unit 
tests for =
my code.

I've ran into a puzzling situation, and I'm looking for suggestio=
ns 
on how to [1] properly test code using JUnit or [2] refactor my code 
s=
o that it can be tested.

The class in question parses a fairly complex tex=
t file and 
constructs a single Java object from it. There is a single publ=
ic 
parse method that returns an instance of this object. Inside this 
publ=
ic parse method several private helper methods are called. 
Basically the j=
ob of the public method is to call the private helper 
methods in the corre=
ct sequence, based on the contents of the file 
being parsed.

Here is my q=
uestion: I want to verify that the logic in parts of 
these private helper =
methods does what I intend. Although I know a 
failure of any of these "log=
ic parts" in a private helper method 
would be reflected in a failure of th=
e public method. However, I want 
to pinpoint which of the "logic parts" fa=
iling.

Have I left the realm of unit testing and moved on to some type of =

functional testing? Do I need to refactor these "logic parts" into 
their =
own private methods, and then use a framework like JUnitX to 
test these pr=
ivate methods? Do I write some beanshell scripts that 
test this logic inst=
ead?

Thanks for any suggestions on how to proceed. I know this problem is =

due to my lack of experience with software testing, and is not a 
problem =
with JUnit.

The Sunburned Surveyor
